# The Lonely Planet guide to the MusÃ©e dâOrsay

![Lonely Planet Editors](https://lp-cms-production.imgix.net/2025-05/LPMarkBlue.png?auto=format,compress&q=72&crop=faces&fit=crop&w=64&h=64)

Jun 6, 2025 • 8 min read

![PARIS, FRANCE - APRIL 15, 2023: Main hall of Orsay Museum, French: Musee d Orsay, in former train station building, Paris, France.  License Type: media  Download Time: 2023-11-04T15:13:26.000Z  User: Norma.PrauseBrewer_LonelyPlanet  Is Editorial: Yes  purchase_order:   ](https://lp-cms-production.imgix.net/2025-06/Shutterstock2321897045.jpg?auto=format,compress&q=72&w=1440&h=810&fit=crop)

The MusÃ©e d'Orsay is one of Parisâ top sights. Hereâs how to best enjoy it. Pyty/Shutterstock

Parisâ Rive Gauche (Left Bank) is the historic stomping ground of artists, tastemakers and cultural icons. To this day, the neighborhood remains an artistic hub, home to the Ãcole des Beaux-Arts and a number of art galleries â including the [MusÃ©e d'Orsay](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/france/paris/st-germain-and-les-invalides/attractions/musee-d-orsay/a/poi-sig/372151/1322788), the second-most-visited art museum in [Paris](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/destinations/france/paris), after [the Louvre](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/articles/guide-to-the-louvre).

Home to [France](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/destinations/france)âs national collection of works from the impressionist, post-impressionist and art nouveau movements (1848 to 1914), the MusÃ©e dâOrsay is housed in the glorious former Gare dâOrsay train station (itself an art nouveau showpiece). Here, youâll find a roll call of masters, with world-renowned works by Ãdouard Manet, Claude Monet, Paul CÃ©zanne, Pierre-Auguste Renoir, Edgar Degas, Camille Pissarro, Vincent van Gogh and many more on glorious display.

To make the most of you visit to this popular museum, weâve put together a guide of what you need to know before you go â and once you get there.

## When should I go to the MusÃ©e dâOrsay?

As you might expect, [crowds are smaller](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/articles/best-time-to-visit-paris) at the MusÃ©e dâOrsay in winter, between November and March. From spring until autumn (April to October), you can expect the museum to be busy, yet there are a number of measures designed to manage high visitor numbers.

According to our local sources, the museum is busier on Tuesdays and Sundays, and that the best time to visit is around the middle of the day, when crowds thin out for a proper lunch break, as the French do. 

The MusÃ©e dâOrsay is closed on Mondays. On Thursdays, the galleries stay open late, with ticket slots starting at 6pm. The last entry is at 9pm, and the museum closes at 9:45pm.

As well as the extraordinary permanent collection, visitors can enjoy temporary exhibitions, small concerts, film screenings, performances and cafe readings. [Check the museumâs website](https://www.musee-orsay.fr/en/whats-on) to time your visit to one of these special events.

![The facade of the MusÃ©e dâOrsay at dusk.](https://lp-cms-production.imgix.net/2025-06/shutterstockRF207050965.jpg?auto=format,compress&q=72&fit=crop)

## A warning about purchasing tickets for the MusÃ©e dâOrsay

You will save time by [pre-purchasing tickets online](https://billetterie.musee-orsay.fr/en-GB/home) and heading to the right queue. If you have a specific time slot, head to queue A2. If you have pre-purchased tickets but without a time slot head to entrance C, queue 1.

If you donât have a ticket and just want to wing it on the day, youâll be joining queue C2.

To save some euros, it is possible to get a ticket combined with entrance to the [MusÃ©e de lâOrangerie](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/france/paris/louvre-and-les-halles/attractions/musee-de-l-orangerie/a/poi-sig/372481/1322719), and to the [MusÃ©e Rodin](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/france/paris/st-germain-and-les-invalides/attractions/musee-rodin/a/poi-sig/372149/1322788). The MusÃ©e dâOrsay is also free on the first Sunday of the month â but you must [book ahead for a specific time slot online](https://www.musee-orsay.fr/fr/agenda/visites-et-ateliers/1er-dimanche-du-mois-gratuit-reservation-obligatoire-0#:~:text=Le%20premier%20dimanche%20du%20mois,Orsay%20est%20gratuit%20pour%20tous%20!).

Itâs also important to note there has been a proliferation of fake MusÃ©e dâOrsay ticket sites. So be sure to buy your tickets from the official site (linked above).

## How much time should I spend at the MusÃ©e dâOrsay?

Itâs almost impossible to view the entire collection in one day. Instead, weâd advise picking one or two areas of interest and use these to direct your exploration. For a fee, audioguides provide commentary from the museumâs curators on over 300 works.

You can also pay to join one of the museumâs themed guided tours. Held daily in English, French and Italian, the 1Â½-hour tours follow themes such as âmasterpieces,â âanimalsâ and âpartiesâ; check the museumâs website for departure times. At busy times, book your tour slot in advance and allow plenty of time to get into the museum to meet up with the group.

Pre-plan your itinerary in the museum by consulting the [online visitor online](https://www.musee-orsay.fr/en/visit/admission-opening-times-tickets).

## Admire the architecture of the MusÃ©e dâOrsay

As you enter the MusÃ©e dâOrsay, youâll immediately notice the layout of the ground floor, with sculptures in two straight rows, and small galleries lining the outer edges of the space.

This museum layout evokes the original railway station. Indeed, when authorities set out to transform the building into a museum, they made the decision to elevate the history of architecture to the status of the history of art, given the sheer significance of the encasing building. Accordingly, architectural drawings by the likes of Gustave Eiffel and Viollet-le-Duc hang alongside works by famous artists.

At the end of the ground floor is a space dedicated to the history of Parisâ urban development. Look below you and youâll notice an intricate scale model of the city as it stood in 1914.

![A woman in a leopard-print blouse takes a photo of a painting depicting a still-life with apples, displayed in a gold frame.](https://lp-cms-production.imgix.net/2025-06/Shutterstock2191628609.jpg?auto=format,compress&q=72&fit=crop)

## Explore the many masterpieces at the MusÃ©e dâOrsay

Most people visit the MusÃ©e dâOrsay for its outstanding collection of impressionist works, with the 5th floor of the museum largely dedicated to the movement. By tracing the galleries in a clockwise direction youâll get a fairly comprehensive overview of the development of the movement and its successors, from impressionism to post-impressionism to neo-impressionism. Here is where the well-known masterpieces such as Monetâs [*Londres, le Parlement*](https://www.musee-orsay.fr/en/artworks/londres-le-parlement-trouee-de-soleil-dans-le-brouillard-1177), Van Goghâs [*Starry Night over the RhÃ´ne*](https://www.musee-orsay.fr/en/artworks/la-nuit-etoilee-78696), and Degasâ sculpture [*La Petite Danseuse de Quatorze Ans*](https://www.musee-orsay.fr/fr/oeuvres/petite-danseuse-de-quatorze-ans-961) are exhibited alongside other fabled modern works, including several of CÃ©zanneâs glorious still lifes.

## Learn more about French cinema

Few know that from its start the MusÃ©e dâOrsay has emphasized the history of cinema and cinematography â innovating an approach that considers film an art rather than a mere technique or entertainment. On the 5th floor, tucked away alongside the impressionist collection, is a gallery tracing the mediumâs history and technical developments, with projections of short clips from pivotal films in the mediumâs history. To complement this venture, the MusÃ©e dâOrsay often holds screenings in its auditorium of some of the most important works of cinema from the early 20th century. Check the official website for a schedule.

## Compare contemporary and historic art

Although the focus of the MusÃ©e dâOrsay is art from the period between 1848 and 1914, several times a year the museum invites major players on the contemporary art scene â past participants have included Jean-Philippe Delhomme, Marlene Dumas and Peter Doig â to curate exhibitions featuring their own works juxtaposed with selections from the permanent collection.

By placing contemporary art in direct dialogue with historical masterpieces, these displays help viewers consider the works with a fresh perspective while emphasizing their enduring importance. On one Thursday evening per month, the museum also hosts âCurious Thursdays,â when young artists from other creative worlds (like dance and music) are invited to perform among the artworks.

## Donât miss these masterpieces at the MusÃ©e d'Orsay

Ãduoard Manetâs [*Le DÃ©jeuner sur lâherbe*](https://www.musee-orsay.fr/fr/oeuvres/le-dejeuner-sur-lherbe-904)

Vincent Van Goghâs *Starry Night Over the RhÃ´ne*

Edgar Degasâ *La Petite Danseuse de Quatorze Ans*

Claude Monetâs *Londres, le Parlement*

Auguste Renoirâs [*Bal du Moulin de la Galette*](https://www.musee-orsay.fr/fr/oeuvres/bal-du-moulin-de-la-galette-497)

Paul CÃ©zanne's *Apples and Oranges*

Gustave Courbetâs [*LâOrigine du Monde*](https://www.musee-orsay.fr/fr/oeuvres/lorigine-du-monde-69330)

## Inspired? Pick up your own art supplies at Magasin Sennelier

Feeling inspired? While youâre in the neighborhood, the nearby [Magasin Sennelier](https://www.magasinsennelier.art/en/) on quai Voltaire is a famous art-supply store that dates back to 1887. Passionate about the chemistry of colors, Gustave Sennelier developed his own range of oil paints using pigments and binders sourced from his European travels. Artists such as CÃ©zanne and Gauguin worked directly with Sennelier to create custom colors; later, the shop innovated with oil pastels for Pablo Picasso. To this day, the *maison* is a rendezvous point for artists who consider Sennelier to be la crÃ¨me de la crÃ¨me.

![People eat at tables in a dining room with elaborate gilt decoration and a painted ceiling.](https://lp-cms-production.imgix.net/2025-06/shutterstock794087509.jpg?auto=format,compress&q=72&fit=crop)

## Where can I eat or drink at the MusÃ©e d'Orsay?

Youâll find a [host of dining options at the museum](https://www.musee-orsay.fr/en/visit/restaurants%20and%20caf%C3%A9s). Its restaurant, simply called âThe Restaurant,â offers a seasonal menu to diners in a stunning gilded salon. Grab a bite or a cup of tea in CafÃ© Campana: the dining room has as its centerpiece the large clock visible at the top of the building.

You can also get lighter bites at one of two cafes, and a kiosk (Le Kiosque du Parvis) that sells sandwiches, falafel and light refreshments. Break up your visit with a pause in the museumâs gilded tearoom, which was formerly the railway stationâs dining room.

Beyond the museum, head to the arcade Beaupassage, where multiple refuellng options range from [Pierre HermÃ©](https://www.pierreherme.com/?utm_source=GMB&utm_medium=GMB&utm_campaign=GMB%20Beaupassage)âs tearoom-like cafe to the hipster coffee spot [% Arabica](https://www.instagram.com/arabica.frn/?hl=en) in the courtyard and [Thierry Marx](https://thierrymarxbakery.fr/)â bakery.

If you want to take your MusÃ©e dâOrsay experience to a luxe level, you could combine it with an evening at what many call the worldâs best restaurant, [Restaurant Guy Savoy](https://www.guysavoy.com/). A temple to gastronomy, this culinary destination is ensconced in the neoclassical Monnaie de Paris and begins with a red-carpeted staircase. Need we say more?

## Is the MusÃ©e dâOrsay child-friendly?

As well as offering free admission to under-18s, the MusÃ©e dâOrsay also offers kid-friendly audioguide options (aimed at the under-12s) and [family-friendly self-guided tours](https://www.petitsmo.fr/les-parcours).

Large strollers need to be checked at the cloakroom, but museum-appropriate strollers are on offer so [your little ones](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/articles/paris-with-kids) donât have to traipse around for hours.

![A view of an elaborate art nouveau building alongside a river in a city.](https://lp-cms-production.imgix.net/2025-06/Shutterstock139359914.jpg?auto=format,compress&q=72&fit=crop)

## What is the best way to get to the MusÃ©e dâOrsay?

The museum is near the metro station SolfÃ©rino on line 12; several buses also stop nearby. If youâre coming via RER, take line C to the MusÃ©e d'Orsay station, directly below the galleries. Thereâs also a Batobus stop outside, if arriving by riverboat is your preferred transport option. As everywhere in Paris, you can walk or cycle for [the most sustainable way to get around town](https://www.lonelyplanet.com/articles/getting-around-paris).

## Is the MusÃ©e dâOrsay accessible?

Yes. All of the museumâs galleries are accessible by wheelchair; there are adapted toilets, access ramps, automatic doors and elevators, too. People with disabilities and one accompanying visitor are also given free admission to the museum. If you have mobility concerns, you can also borrow a wheelchair or a folded seat to make your visit more comfortable.

*This article was adapted from Lonely Planetâs* [Paris](https://shop.lonelyplanet.com/products/paris) *guidebook, published in March 2024.*

It sits atop a hill, the highest point in the city. It is one of the best sections to walk around in. You'll find street artists, historic monuments and quaint cafes. And you're close to the one and only Moulin Rouge. Start with the Basilica of the Sacred Heart of Paris, arguably the most beautiful church in the city. Including the more celebrated Notre Dame. Climb the 300 steps to the top of the dome and enjoy the most panoramic view of the city, notwithstanding the Eiffel Tower. Adjacent to the basilica is a green space called Square Louise-Michel, a great spot for a picnic. At the bottom of the hill lies the indescribable I Love You Wall at Square Jehan-Rictus, an art piece that includes "I love you" written 311 times in 250 languages. For drinks, stop at the Cafe des Deux Moulins. For breakfast, the Hardware Societe on Rue Lamarck is recommended. For a cup of coffee, visit the Spree cafe and art gallery on Rue la Vieuville. Aside from the Basilica of the Sacred Heart, the district is known as an art hotspot where Picasso, van Gogh and Renoir were among the painters who once lived and worked in Montmartre. If you're looking for a rendition of the famous "can-can" dance, the Moulin Rouge cabaret is on Boulevard de Clichy, on the outskirts of the Montmartre neighborhood. The district also features several museums, including the Salvador Dali Museum with 300 works of the surrealist artist, the Montmartre Museum that showcases the district's history through paintings, sculptures and posters, and the Museum of Romantic Life. The Pere Lachaise is the most celebrated cemetery in Paris, the final resting place for Oscar Wilde and Jim Morrison, but the Cemetary of Montmartre also attracts a crowd. Among 20,000 burial plots is Emile Zola. For trivia buffs, Montmartre is home to the oldest pedestrian street in Paris, the Rue Saint-Rustique. *   [![Image 252](https://dynamic-media-cdn.tripadvisor.com/media/photo-f/01/2e/70/7f/avatar066.jpg?w=100&h=-1&s=1)](https://www.tripadvisor.com/ClientLink?value=OGZQXy9Qcm9maWxlLzg2NlRheWxvckJfaXJt)      [Taylor B](https://www.tripadvisor.com/ClientLink?value=OGZQXy9Qcm9maWxlLzg2NlRheWxvckJfaXJt)Chicago, IL 8,857 contributions    0        [Which side of the Seine do you prefer?](https://www.tripadvisor.com/ShowUserReviews-g187147-d189683-r1017314094-Seine_River-Paris_Ile_de_France.html) The Seine River is to Paris what the Thames is to London, what the Mississippi is to New Orleans, what the Nile is to Cairo. Cutting through the very heart of Paris, it is the epicenter of the vibrant French capital. The gentle waterway is an integral part of the city and its fascinating history. The two banks of the Seine are referred to as La Rive Gauche (the Left Bank) and a La Rive Droite (the Right Bank). Both banks are listed as UNESCO World Heritage Sites and each offer their own distinct flavor of the Parisian experience. The Left Bank has long been linked to writers, artists and cafe culture. Hemingway, Picasso and Matisse all once called La Rive Gauche their home. Grab an old-fashioned hot chocolate at Le Deux Magots, explore the winding alleyways of the Latin Quarter and browse the bouquinistes set up along the river, independent book vendors selling old books, magazines and collectibles from iconic green metal boxes. Meanwhile, the Right Bank has always had stronger links with commerce and trade, the wealthier side of the Seine. It also lays claim to many of Paris' most notable attractions, including the Louvre Museum, Notre Dame Cathedral, the Eiffel Tower and the Arc de Triomphe. Over a dozen historic bridges connect the Left and Right bank of the Seine as the river snakes through the heart of Paris, most notably the Pont Neuf, Pont Alexander 111 and Pont des Arts. For a relaxing way to take in all the best views from the Seine, a two-hour riverboat tour is highly recommended. The Place des Vosges, the oldest square in Paris. The architecturally imposing Hotel de Ville. On rue Montmorency is the half-timbered house of Nicolas Flamel, which was built in 1407. Visit the Baroque church of Saint-Louis Saint Paul with its colorful clock and painting by Eugene Delacroix. The George Pompidou Centre is home to France's largest collection of modern and contemporary art. The Galerie Perrotin is the most celebrated art gallery in Paris. See the musee Cognacz-Jay, a Parisian mansion from the Age of Enlightenment, and the Musee Carnavalet with memorabilia from the French Revolution. The house of writer Victor Hugo, which has been preserved as it was when the author of Les Miserables was alive. The Musee of Jewish Art and History is located in the Hotel de Saint-Aigan. For fashion lovers, Le Marais is one of the best areas for shoppers. BHV Marais dates to 1856. Other go-to destinations are Empreintes, Gucci, Karl Langerfeld and John Galliano. Tired? Need a break? The district features such noted restaurants as Glou, Robert et Louise, Brasserie Bofinger, Le Bel Canto and L'Ambroisie. And bakeries operated by gourmet pastry chefs such as Pierre Herme, Yann Courveur and Christophe Michalak. On the rue de Bretogne is the oldest street market in Paris, Marche Couvert des Enfants Rouges, with its colorful stalls, fresh produce, flowers and small dishes. Located in the heart of the city on the Ile de la Cite, it was built in the middle of the 13th century by King Louis 1X to house the most prestigious relics of the Passion of Christ--the Crown of Thorns and a fragment of the True Cross. The Crown of Thorns was moved to Notre Dame on 1806. The 1,113 stained glass windows relate scenes of the Old and New Testaments and tell the story of the world, according to the Bible. Two-thirds of the windows are original. Visitors are awed by 15 exceptional windows of breathtaking dimensions, 15 meters high in the nave and 13 meters high in the choir. Acquisition of the famous relics and construction of Sainte-Chapelle increased the prestige of France. Paris became, in the eyes of medieval Europe, a "new Jerusalem" and thus the beacon of Western Christianity. The building consists of an upper level, the upper chapel in which the relics of the Passion of Christ are exalted, and the lower chapel serving the palace staff. The spire rises to 75 meters above the ground. The church is open to the public daily from 9 to 7 but it hasn't been used for worship since the French Revolution. However, the monument still shines today as one of the most extraordinary masterpieces of the High Gothic style. One warning: Sainte-Chapelle isn't air conditioned.
